title: Dorsey's First Tweet Sells as NFT for $2.9 Million
summary: CEO of Malaysian blockchain company is winning bidder in auction launched by Twitter co-founder. The first tweet that Twitter Inc. Chief Executive Jack Dorsey posted to the microblogging site in 2006 has sold as a nonfungible token for about $2.9 million, the latest digital collectible to haul in more than $1 million amid a flurry of interest from buyers.

title: U.S., Allies Sanction China Over Treatment of Uyghurs
summary: Move by U.S., Canada, U.K. and EU is type of joint action sought by Biden administration; it draws retaliation from Beijing. The U.S., Canada and allies in Europe leveled sanctions against Chinese officials over the repression of mainly Muslim Uyghurs in a coordinated blacklisting that is part of Biden administration efforts to forge coalitions against Beijing.

title: Reconsidering Times v. Sullivan
summary: An influential judge says the 'actual malice' standard needs revision.. Senior Judge Laurence Silberman of the D.C. Circuit Court of Appeals knows how to court media outrage. His gun-control opinion became the template for the Supreme Court's landmark Heller decision that the Second Amendment is an individual right not limited to militias. Now he's caused a stir with a dissent suggesting that the landmark libel ruling, New York Times v. Sullivan, should be reconsidered.

title: Leon Black Steps Down as Apollo Global's Chairman
summary: Former SEC Chairman Jay Clayton assumes role, as investment giant continues overhaul stemming from Black's ties to Jeffrey Epstein. Leon Black, the billionaire co-founder of Apollo Global Management Inc., is stepping down as chairman of the investment giant in an unexpected move that is the latest in a governance overhaul kicked off by revelations of his ties to disgraced financier Jeffrey Epstein.

title: Universal Basic Income Hype
summary: A ballyhooed study proves much less than advertised.. Perhaps you've heard that a universal basic income is an idea whose time has come. Liberals are hyping the supposed success of UBI from a small experiment in Stockton, Calif. On closer scrutiny, it looks like a case study in politics influencing academic research.

title: A Warning to Pelosi on Iowa
summary: Can she hold her caucus together to overturn a House election?. The eight-seat House Democratic majority has been remarkably disciplined so far in 2021, passing radical legislation on elections and unions with few defections. But the limits of loyalty to Speaker Nancy Pelosi will be tested as the party moves to overturn an Iowa House race and expel from Congress the certified winner.

title: Hybrid Work Plans Could Bring New Challenges
summary: Companies preparing for a mix of office and remote work face obstacles ranging from scheduling to collaboration and performance assessment. As employers solidify plans to bring workers back into the office while still allowing them to do some remote work, many are finding that adjusting to this new normal won't be easy.

title: Matt Zames Steps Down as Cerberus Capital's President
summary: Departure came as a surprise to Cerberus executives. Matt Zames is stepping down as president of Cerberus Capital Management LP after only three years in the role, the private-equity firm said Monday.

title: Thank You, Kay Coles James
summary: The president of the Heritage Foundation steps down.. Kay Coles James announced her resignation Monday as president of the Heritage Foundation, and who replaces her will say a good deal about the future of the political right. Founded in 1973, Heritage helped guide the Reagan Administration with its "Mandate for Leadership" and remains a leading conservative voice.

title: The Dubious Origins of Long Covid
summary: Echoes of chronic fatigue in the effort to blame the coronavirus for a host of questionable symptoms.. 'Long Covid," or post-Covid syndrome, is an emerging condition that has attracted great media attention-and now federal funding. The National Institutes of Health last month announced a $1.15 billion initiative to research the "prolonged health consequences" of Covid-19 infection.

title: Marty Walsh Confirmed as Labor Secretary
summary: Boston mayor has championed organized labor and pledged to focus on worker safety amid the pandemic. WASHINGTON-The Senate on Monday confirmed Marty Walsh as Labor secretary, sending an advocate of organized labor to an agency that has signaled its intent to focus on worker protections and inequality in the labor market during the Biden administration.

title: A 1,000-Word Story on My Friend's Wall
summary: A painting I admired in my youth is up for auction at Sotheby's.. A childhood friend emailed recently. Morris and I have spoken twice in the past 50 years, but a rush of excitement came over me when I saw the subject line: "Henry Koerner."

title: America's Back-Against a Wall
summary: Three problems stand athwart Biden's plans for a rules-based international order.. Anyone who thought international politics would calm down once Donald Trump left center stage has had a rude awakening. After the Alaska confrontation between top U.S. and Chinese officials and the slanging match between Presidents Biden and Vladimir Putin, the world is as fraught as ever. American relations with Russia are at their lowest ebb since the Kennedy administration and U.S.-China relations at their frostiest since Henry Kissinger went to China in 1971, while Beijing and Moscow are more closely aligned than at any time since the death of Stalin.

title: The Christian Baker Who Said 'No'
summary: Jack Phillips is again in court for refusing to bake a cake with a message he objects to.. Jack Phillips is America's most famous baker. People have taken him all the way to the Supreme Court in hopes of getting it to force him to bake them one of his custom cakes. This week he's back in the dock, again defending his refusal to bake a custom cake with a message he says goes against his Christian faith.

title: 'Rock Me on the Water' Review: Something New Came Along
summary: America changed dramatically in the 1970s. The movies, music and television shows coming out of Los Angeles led the way.. People of a certain age will remember-with embarrassment or nostalgia, or both-"Rock Me on the Water," a seminal song from Jackson Browne's 1972 debut album. Ron Brownstein borrows the title for his admiring, perhaps occasionally too admiring, cultural history of Los Angeles in the early 1970s. He believes that, in those few years, L.A. came to dominate America's popular culture, transforming not only the music scene but movies, television and politics as well.

title: Notable & Quotable: Meat Wars
summary: 'Gov. Polis announced a statewide "Meat Out Day" to be celebrated on March 20 where Coloradans are asked to abstain from all things meat.'. D.J. Summers reporting for Denver's KDVR-TV, March 19:

title: New York City Venues Reopen but Raise Covid-19 Concerns
summary: A dance event at Park Avenue Armory was canceled after three performers tested positive for the virus. The coronavirus-related cancellation of a dance event at a New York City cultural venue has prompted concerns about whether such spaces can be safely reopened at this time.

title: Jury Selection Nears Close in Derek Chauvin Case
summary: The majority-white jury of 14 is more diverse than the state of Minnesota and Hennepin County. Lawyers in the trial of the former Minneapolis police officer accused of murder in the death of George Floyd are close to seating a full-and diverse-jury panel to decide a case that sparked a national reckoning on race and policing.

title: Turkish Lira Plunges After Erdogan Fires Central-Bank Chief
summary: Turkey's currency is on course for its biggest single-day selloff in almost three years. Turkey's currency tumbled 7.5% on Monday, in its biggest single-day selloff since 2018, after the abrupt ouster of the central-bank governor last week.

title: A Man in Iowa
summary: This college student is no snowflake.. Your humble correspondent, a little sore after playing outside with the kids on a sunny weekend, is feeling even more humble considering how somebody else spent his weekend.

title: Technology Shares Rebound
summary: Nasdaq Composite rises more than 1%, a signal of strength for tech stocks. U.S. stocks climbed on Monday, as gains in technology stocks powered the Nasdaq Composite higher.

title: 'Chemtrails Over the Country Club' by Lana Del Rey Review: Tainted by Expectation
summary: The album features the singer's signature moodiness but lacks the vivid imagery that made its predecessor, 'Norman F-ing Rockwell!,' a smash success..

title: Alleged North Korean Operative Makes First U.S. Court Appearance
summary: Mun Chol Myong, extradited from Malaysia, faces charges of helping North Korea flout U.S. sanctions. WASHINGTON-An alleged North Korean intelligence operative appeared in federal court in Washington on Monday to face charges of laundering funds to evade U.S. and United Nations sanctions, in the first such prosecution of its kind as relations between the Biden administration and North Korea have had a rocky start.

title: New York to Open Covid-19 Vaccine Eligibility to Residents Aged 50 and Above
summary: Move lowers age requirement by a decade; more than 13% of state fully vaccinated. New York state will expand vaccine eligibility to those 50 years of age and older starting Tuesday, Gov. Andrew Cuomo said.

title: Caesars Sues Insurance Carriers, Saying They Declined to Cover Losses
summary: Casino and hotel company brings suit against insurance carriers over pandemic-related claims. Caesars Entertainment Inc. sued a group of insurance carriers, accusing them of declining to cover an estimated loss of more than $2 billion because of the Covid-19 pandemic.

title: Supreme Court to Consider Boston Marathon Bomber's Death Sentence
summary: Justice Department sought high court review after appeals court tossed death sentence for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev. WASHINGTON-The Supreme Court agreed to consider the Justice Department's bid to reinstate a death sentence for convicted Boston Marathon bomber Dzhokhar Tsarnaev.

title: Washington, D.C., Statehood Divides Congressional Hearing
summary: Democrats push statehood as civil-rights priority, while Republicans see constitutional issues, power grab. Democrats and Republicans sparred Monday over statehood for Washington, D.C., with proponents saying residents were due full voting rights and critics calling it a partisan power grab and arguing the city's unique status raised constitutional hurdles.

title: Bond Rout Hits Safest Corporate Debt
summary: Returns on investment-grade corporate bonds have faltered amid broader selloff. The bond-market rout is dealing a particular blow to investors' bets on the safest U.S. companies, dragging returns on investment-grade corporate debt to their second-worst start on record.

title: Supreme Court Shows Inclination to Limit Union-Access Law
summary: Arguments reveal differences on whether California growers have right to compensation for letting organizers onto their property to speak to farmworkers. WASHINGTON-The Supreme Court seemed ready after Monday arguments to pare back union organizers' ability to visit farmworkers in California's agricultural fields, but it was unclear whether the justices viewed the case narrowly or as an opportunity to dramatically expand property rights.

title: Knotel to Name WeWork Veteran Michael Gross as CEO
summary: With the hire, the startup's new owners are signaling a clear break from the company's former CEO and co-founder, Amol Sarva. Knotel Inc. is planning to announce that former WeWork Vice Chairman Michael Gross will join as chief executive, as the real-estate startup seeks a turnaround after it filed for bankruptcy.

title: Vaccine Fight Between EU and U.K. Threatens to Escalate
summary: Officials on both sides are in talks to prevent bans of exports of Covid-19 shots and vaccination supplies. A fight between the European Union and the U.K. over vaccine supplies is demonstrating how securing national access to doses can generate conflict among U.S. allies and underlining the vulnerability of successful Covid-19 vaccine rollouts to the breakdown of international supply chains.

title: Fed's Powell Says Recovery Is Far From Complete
summary: Central bank will continue supporting U.S. economy 'for as long as it takes,' chairman says. WASHINGTON-Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell reiterated Monday that the U.S. economy's recovery remains far from complete despite recent improvement and that the central bank plans to continue providing support.

title: New York City High Schools Reopen After Covid-19 Shutdowns
summary: About 55,000 high-school students return to school buildings as mayor lays out plans to allow more students back into classrooms. New York City public high schools reopened for in-person learning on Monday, and Mayor Bill de Blasio laid out plans to allow fully remote students to return to classrooms this academic year.

title: Her Job Is to Convince South Koreans to Use 5G. It Hasn't Been Easy.
summary: Jeon Jin-soo of SK Telecom wants to show consumers how to incorporate the technology into daily life. But for now there isn't that much to show.. SEOUL-Jeon Jin-soo wants consumers to love 5G. But she understands why they're not head over heels right now.

title: Saudi Arabia Offers Cease-Fire Deal in Yemen
summary: Kingdom's foreign minister announces new proposal for a cease-fire with the Iran-aligned Houthis ahead of political negotiations. RIYADH-Saudi Arabia unveiled a proposal for a cease-fire aimed at disentangling itself from Yemen's civil war, as rebel forces press an offensive and the Biden administration seeks to extricate the U.S. from the six-year-old conflict.

title: Hardwood Four (Tuesday Crossword, March 23)
Microsoft Prepares to Reopen Its Offices and Enter Hybrid-Work Era
summary: Software company expects partial remote work to be routine for many of its jobs, even after Covid-19 pandemic. Microsoft Corp. , one of the first American companies to ask staff to shift to remote work more than a year ago as the coronavirus pandemic hit, is ready to begin welcoming employees back to the office.

title: Humana Opens Search for New CFO as Brian Kane Resigns
summary: Mr. Kane will step down on June 1 and serve as an adviser for the rest of this year. Health insurer Humana Inc. is looking for a new chief financial officer following the resignation of Brian Kane, who will step down on June 1.

summary: Selections from 'Bruno the Beekeeper' by Aneta Františka Holasová. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: FirstEnergy Appoints Chief Compliance Officer Amid Bribery Probe
summary: Ohio utility recruits industry veteran from a New Jersey energy company. FirstEnergy Corp. said Monday that Antonio Fernández will serve as chief compliance officer, effective April 12, as the Ohio utility works to put a bribery scandal behind it.

title: No Inflation Panic Yet, but There Is Concern
summary: The Federal Reserve is capable of nipping any surge of inflation, but has made clear it will be behind the curve as inflation rises.. Alan S. Blinder is correct that with the slack in the economy and high unemployment there is no risk of wage inflation ("There's No Need to Panic About a Little Inflation," op-ed, March 16). But he overlooks price inflation, which happens when too many dollars are chasing too few goods and services. With recent stimulus payments and high stock prices Americans are feeling wealthy. Plus they have pent-up demand after a year of being shut in. They are ready to spend, but as increasing demand begins to outstrip supply, prices must rise to bring things into balance.

title: A Case for the Continued Wearing of Masks
summary: When Gov. Ron DeSantis withdrew statewide mask mandates for gyms, I enforced a mask requirement in the boutique gym I own in Florida.. It appears that the state of Texas will provide a nice little test of how cowed the American public will remain, after a full year of the government and the press engaged in the ruination of society with Covid lockdowns and mask mandates ("On Business: No Shoes, No Mask, No Service?," Exchange, March 13). If some restaurants require their patrons to wear a mask when away from their tables, and some restaurants allow their customers to appear with bare faces, then some places will do a booming business serving the free people of Texas, and the rest will do business with those Texans who have no problem remaining in health bondage.

title: A Closer Look
summary: Illustrations from 'Moimoi: Look at Me!' by Jun Ichihara. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Amazon's Policy Could Provoke Antitrust Move
summary: Although I find Amazon's foray into book banning sad, I am heartened by what I hope will be the consequences.. Regarding Ryan T. Anderson's "Amazon Won't Let You Read My Book" (op-ed, March 17): Not long ago I downloaded a sample of "When Harry Became Sally," but remained unsure whether I wanted to spend the money to buy the full book. Now that Amazon has said "not from us," I made sure to buy the full ebook right away (from Apple Books).

title: A Recent College Graduate Starts His Engineering Career in 5G
summary: Ryan Juraidini, 23, wishes more people understood just how significant the technology is. When Ryan Juraidini tells people he's a 5G systems engineer at Nokia Corp. , he's usually met with a blank stare. "They're like, 'I have zero idea what you just said.' "

title: Fake Memories Can Be Planted and Then Reversed, Study Finds
summary: German study points to possible techniques for recognizing and correcting erroneous recollections. Researchers in Germany and the U.K. said they were able to plant false memories and then help study volunteers root them out, work that suggests potential remedies to ease the problem of erroneous recollections.

title: Lakers Star Elgin Baylor Dies at Age 86
summary: The NBA legend passed away of natural causes in Los Angeles. Elgin Baylor, the Lakers' 11-time NBA All-Star, died Monday of natural causes. He was 86.

title: A Closer Look
summary: Selections from 'The Happiness of a Dog With a Ball in Its Mouth' by Bruce Handy, illustrated by Hyewon Yum. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: One Year Into the Pandemic, New York City Faces a Lopsided Recovery
summary: Industries that power the city weathered the pandemic better than expected, but crisis delivered disproportionate blow to most vulnerable residents. A year after the coronavirus pandemic ground New York City's economy to a near standstill, most big companies and white-collar employees have emerged inconvenienced but intact, while many small businesses and low-wage workers are still struggling to stay afloat.

title: A Harvard Professor Brings 5G to M.B.A. Students
summary: David Yoffie has students look for business opportunities that the wireless technology could bring. In David Yoffie's Harvard Business School class, he wants his management students to envision the business opportunities 5G could bring that they one day could profit from. And he encourages them to think big.

title: Tight Supply Is Limiting Home Sales at Start of Spring
summary: Sales fell 6.6% in February; U.S. has more Realtors than houses for sale right now. The record-low number of homes on the market is limiting purchases heading into the spring selling season.

title: Quarles Presses Banks to Stop Use of Libor for New Contracts by Year End
summary: Fed vice chairman sees 'no scenario' under which the interest-rate benchmark continues past 2023. WASHINGTON-A top Federal Reserve official pressed banks Monday to stop using the London interbank offered rate on new transactions by the end of 2021, ratcheting up warnings over the interest-rate benchmark that global policy makers moved to scrap after concluding it was balky and prone to manipulation.

title: Filibuster Debate Tears at Biden and Senate
summary: Pressure builds as Democrats see Republican filibusters as main obstacle to next big priorities. When Richard Arenberg, a longtime Democratic congressional staffer, co-wrote a book in 2012 defending the Senate's filibuster, he was pleasantly surprised to get a nice reaction from a high-level reviewer: He received a complimentary note from then-Vice President Joe Biden.

title: Western Culture Elites Are Giving Away Lenin's Rope
summary: How can a nation prevail in an ideological struggle when its leaders believe its values are evil?. 'The capitalists will sell us the rope with which we will hang them."

title: After Covid, Services Are Where the Trade Action Is
summary: The pandemic has showcased the digital economy, where the U.S. has enormous comparative advantages.. The U.S. economy's service sector was hit hard by the Covid-19 pandemic. Lately, however, it is showing signs of bouncing back. In January, the ISM Non-Manufacturing Index recorded its highest level since February 2019. The index dipped again last month, though, which should spur President Biden to make a priority of eliminating barriers to U.S. exports of services.

title: Why Finance Executives Rely on Supply-Chain Finance: A Guide to the Financing Tool
summary: Companies are setting up programs to improve working capital and cut costs while disclosing few details. The struggles of Greensill Capital have shone a light on the increasing use of supply-chain financing, a tool that gives companies the ability to extend their payment terms to vendors.

title: Not a Bad Time to Lose a Major Chip Deal
summary: Applied Materials' prospects look strong with a chip shortage boosting equipment demand. Applied Materials will be fine without Kokusai Electric. But the longer term health of the semiconductor equipment market may depend on the global production shortage outlasting U.S.-China tensions, which is hardly a sure thing.

title: NCAA Withheld Use of 'March Madness' Brand From Women's Basketball
summary: The NCAA used the trademark phrase to make the men's tournament a lucrative juggernaut. It also declined to use it for the growing women's championship.. The National Collegiate Athletic Association has built its trademarked "March Madness" phrase into one of the most powerful brands in sports. It's plastered on the courts, arenas and broadcasts for the lucrative NCAA men's basketball tournament-and absent from the women's tournament.

title: Rights Group Asks FCC to Punish Chinese State Broadcaster
summary: A group that has helped force CCTV off the air in the U.K. over airing forced confessions takes its case to the U.S.. A group that helped force China's state broadcaster off U.K. airwaves is taking its case to the U.S. by asking the Federal Communications Commission to punish China Central Television for airing information it knew was false.

title: Federal Reserve Payments to the Treasury Department Rose in 2020
summary: The central bank sent 58% more in profits to the federal government's coffers last year. WASHINGTON-The Federal Reserve sent more profits to the Treasury Department last year as the income from its swelling asset holdings offset the impact of lower interest rates.

title: Deliveroo Aims for $12 Billion Valuation in London IPO
summary: Amazon positioned to reap gain from listing, which follows in the footsteps of U.S. peer DoorDash. LONDON-Deliveroo, backed by Amazon.com Inc. , set a price range for its planned London listing with an upward valuation of $12 billion, posing a test for continued investor appetite in online food-delivery services.

title: How to Talk to Your Child About Drugs and Alcohol
summary: Pandemic-driven anxiety has some teenagers turning to alcohol and drugs. Author Jessica Lahey offers advice to parents for keeping kids on track.. Adults are increasing their use of alcohol and drugs to cope with pandemic-related stress. Jessica Lahey worries that many teens will be tempted to do the same.

title: A Chef Who Can't Smell? Covid Forces Some Creative Solutions
summary: Food and wine professionals are trying new ideas to cope with changes in palates; 'eating chilies, chewing mint'. The first thing Tom Ramsey tasted after temporarily losing his ability to taste and smell was a tray of hospital food. For the New Orleans-based executive chef and certified sommelier, who contracted Covid in late January, the dish was sublime.

title: Japan Charges Father-Son Team With Aiding Ghosn Escape
summary: Michael and Peter Taylor engineered Ghosn's escape plan involving a bullet train from Tokyo to Osaka and a private jet, indictment says. TOKYO-Japanese prosecutors charged an American father-son team with assisting Carlos Ghosn, the former Nissan Motor Co. and Renault SA chairman, in his escape from Japan aboard a private jet.

title: TikTok Doesn't Pose Overt U.S. National Security Threat, Researchers Say
summary: Study by university cybersecurity group finds no evidence of 'overtly malicious behavior' in short-video app's code. HONG KONG-The computer code underlying TikTok doesn't pose a national security threat to the U.S., according to a new study by university cybersecurity researchers.

title: Powell Says Congressional Support Likely Needed to Adopt Fully Digital Dollar
summary: Central bank has long been considering a digital currency. Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell said Monday that the U.S. central bank is actively exploring the launch of a fully digital dollar and would move to adopt such an offering only with the support of the nation's elected leaders.

title: U.K. Investigating Penguin Random House's Simon & Schuster Takeover
summary: Regulator is examining proposed merger on the grounds it may lessen competition. The U.K.'s competition regulator said it is investigating Penguin Random House's proposed acquisition of rival publisher Simon & Schuster, a deal that would create a behemoth in the book industry.

title: FCC Chief in Charge of America's 5G Rollout Confronts a Long To-Do List
summary: Jessica Rosenworcel has inherited a litany of crises and controversies. Mobile devices cover the modern world with billions of wireless signals, a figure expected to grow several-fold once 5G technology is commonplace.

title: Turkey's Central Bank Chooses the Wrong Kind of Heterodoxy
summary: The country's fight against inflation needs a consistent currency policy including, yes, higher interest rates. Economic policy is undergoing a bit of a revolution right now, with many once-heterodox ideas about growth, inflation and monetary policy finding validation. Turkey's faith that it can tame inflation by lowering interest rates is unlikely to be among them.

title: Tips on How to Return to an Outdoor Workout Routine
summary: For those eager to emerge from a long winter indoors, start slow and mix it up. The sun is out, the ground is thawed and you are ready to lace up your sneakers and run. Not so fast, Usain Bolt.

title: Zoom Wants You to Zoom Even When Using Other Companies' Apps
summary: Video-call platform plans to license its technology in an attempt to extend the firm's Covid-19 boom. After a year in which Zoom Video Communications Inc.'s software became the go-to video-call app for many people stuck at home, the tech company now is trying to get other businesses to adapt it as their own.

title: Oil Giant Aramco's Shares Remain a Curiosity
summary: Despite robust operating results, investors have no more reason to buy into the Saudi oil giant than they did at the 2019 initial public offering. Oil giant Saudi Aramco's first full year as one of the world's largest public companies was marked by a crude price war, a global pandemic and proliferating decarbonization promises. The crisis showed both the resilience that the company promised and its political role that has kept international investors away.

title: Kansas City Southern, Tesla, Support.com, Synnex: What to Watch When the Stock Market Opens Today
summary: Futures suggested technology shares would lead gains. Here's what we're watching before Monday's trading action begins.

title: Street Violence in Portland Makes Reopening Economy Difficult
summary: Resume Subscription. PORTLAND, Ore.-When the fence that had surrounded the federal courthouse here was removed earlier this month, city leaders touted it as a sign that Portland was returning to normal after nine months of protests that often turned violent.

title: China Tries Second Canadian at Center of Diplomatic Standoff
summary: Espionage trial of researcher began days after a similar hearing for Canadian Michael Spavor. BEIJING-Chinese authorities opened and closed the espionage trial of the second Canadian at the center of a long-running standoff with both Canada and the U.S. without delivering a verdict.

title: Even Jil Sander Doesn't Know The Secret To Buying Clothes From Her Hit Uniqlo Collaboration
summary: Ahead of the new +J launch on March 25, the designer tells us about the new collection and what she thinks of eBay resales. In our series My Monday Morning, self-motivated people tell WSJ. how they start off the week.

title: NFTs Spur a Digital Land Grab-in Videogame Worlds
summary: Investors and gamers are buying millions of dollars worth of land that exists only in videogames. Investors are pouring millions of dollars into land. But these lush fields and rolling hills only exist within videogames.

title: PPP Loan Changes Came Too Late for Smallest Businesses
summary: Some owners push for retroactive relief after they filed for loans before rules were eased in March. As Congress considers extending the government's flagship small business coronavirus-aid plan, some of the smallest businesses want government officials to make some recent changes in the program retroactive.

title: An Extreme Method for Stress Management Pushes for the Mainstream
summary: Resume Subscription. Sitting in a barrel chest-high in ice cubes seems more like torture than a birthday treat.

title: Tony La Russa Returns to the Dugout After a Decade Away
summary: After a long rebuild, the White Sox are World Series contenders. They are turning to a 76-year-old manager who hasn't been in the dugout for a decade.. Chicago White Sox general manager Rick Hahn has long envisioned a spring like this one, when the team he helped rebuild would enter the season as one of the best in baseball. But he never could have expected who would be occupying the manager's office when the White Sox got there: Hall-of-Famer Tony La Russa, a 76-year-old who last led a dugout a decade ago.

title: AstraZeneca Shot Is Safe, 79% Effective in Latest U.S. Trials
summary: Drug maker said it would prepare to request emergency authorization in the U.S. in coming weeks. AstraZeneca PLC's Covid-19 vaccine was shown to be safe and 79% effective in preventing symptomatic disease in widely anticipated U.S. clinical trials, providing a vote of confidence for the shot and a pathway for its authorization in the U.S.

title: Blackstone's Crown Deal Has Dice Loaded in Its Favor
summary: The private-equity giant's offer for casino operator Crown Resorts has some of the hallmarks of a good deal. Financial markets are often compared to casinos and financiers to gamblers. Sometimes that turns out to be true quite literally: Blackstone is placing a timely bet in Crown Resorts . That bid looks likely to turn out well.

title: High-Income Tax Avoidance Far Larger Than Thought, New Paper Estimates
summary: The very top sliver of high-income Americans may underreport their income at levels far beyond what was suggested by prior IRS research, according to a new paper. WASHINGTON-The top sliver of high-income Americans dodge significantly more in income taxes than the Internal Revenue Service's methods had previously assumed, according to forthcoming estimates from IRS researchers and academic economists.

title: Netanyahu Pins Election Hopes on Vaccine Drive
summary: The country's longest-serving leader has seen his right-wing base splinter, but could gain from Israel's successful inoculation effort. TEL AVIV-After two years and three elections, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is banking on Israel's world-leading vaccination program to break years of political deadlock in Tuesday's national elections.

title: Stock Market Reshuffle Has Room to Run
summary: Rising interest rates have differing effects on companies at different stages of maturity, which is why things are looking good for cyclicals. The economy's prospects are looking up, but so are interest rates. That has been roiling the stock market, hammering the shares of the fast-growing companies that, until recently, have been investors' favorites while sending the shares of companies that didn't do as well during the pandemic higher.

title: Vaccination Megasites Lean on Enterprise Tech to Keep the Line Moving
summary: Beyond the actual vaccine, cloud computing and a robust network are proving to be the top tools at mass vaccination sites. Popup Covid-19 vaccination sites in convention centers, shopping malls and stadiums are relying on digital enterprise technology to handle a looming upswing in inoculations, as more Americans become eligible to receive a shot, healthcare groups and information-technology leaders say.

title: U.S., China Climate Envoys to Meet Despite Frosty Alaska Talks
summary: Tuesday's meeting tests a Biden administration strategy to engage on climate while competing in other areas. HONG KONG-The U.S. and China are tiptoeing toward cooperation on climate change despite recent and testy high-level talks, with the two governments' chief climate envoys scheduled to come together for formal discussions this week.

title: Companies Offer Investors a Glimpse at Employee Turnover
summary: CFOs evaluate how much to disclose about hirings and firings under new regulation. U.S. companies are sharing more details about employee turnover as part of new disclosure requirements. But for some investors, the effort doesn't go far enough because finance chiefs handpick the information they provide.

title: Hospitals Hide Pricing Data From Search Results
summary: Webpages for hundreds of hospitals require users to click through to find prices, undermining federal transparency rule, Journal analysis shows. Hospitals that have published their previously confidential prices to comply with a new federal rule have also blocked that information from web searches with special coding embedded on their websites, according to a Wall Street Journal examination.

title: ESG Rules From Europe Challenge U.S. Fund Managers
summary: Big U.S. firms have to disclose climate, diversity and governance data for investments by funds marketed in the EU. Scores of U.S. fund managers are being forced to comply with sweeping new European rules on climate and other sustainable-finance issues, requiring them to disclose the potential harm their investments could do to the environment and society.

title: Cruise Lines Fear Another Lost Summer
summary: Resume Subscription. PORT CANAVERAL, Fla.-Terminal Three, a cavernous $155 million structure built for Carnival Cruises, is decked out with the company's signature blue paint, hundreds of beechwood seats and a posh VIP room with table lamps so new that sales tags still hang from some.

title: Miami Beach Acts to Rein In Spring Break Revelers
summary: Local officials feared that the crowds would impede efforts to drive down Covid-19 cases. The city of Miami Beach is entering the week with an evening curfew and other restrictions aimed at curbing nightly raucous partying that local officials feared would lead to escalating violence and impede efforts to drive down Covid-19 cases.

title: Marketers Plan Giveaways for Covid-19 Vaccine Recipients
summary: Krispy Kreme gives free doughnuts, e-commerce rewards app Drop offers $50 in points for vaccination selfies. For more than a year, companies have tried to hone their advertising to reflect the different phases of the Covid-19 pandemic. As the U.S. undertakes the largest vaccination campaign in modern history, two companies are targeting the newly inoculated in what could be the start of the next phase of coronavirus marketing.

title: Food Chain (Monday Crossword, March 22)
Blackstone Bids to Buy Australia's Crown Resorts
summary: Deal valuing Crown at around $6 billion hinges on regulators maintaining casino licenses. SYDNEY- Blackstone Group Inc. made a takeover offer for Australian casino operator Crown Resorts Ltd. valued at $6 billion, as regulators investigate Crown's business practices and threaten to rescind its casinos licenses.

title: Homeland Security Secretary Defends Border Policy Amid Surge
summary: 'We will not expel young, vulnerable children,' says DHS Secretary Alejandro Mayorkas; Republicans say Biden's policies have made the situation worse. WASHINGTON-Homeland Security Secretary Alejandro Mayorkas defended his department's handling of a surge of migrants at the southern U.S. border, blaming the Trump administration for much of the current situation and saying that the department is building capacity to properly house unaccompanied children as quickly as possible.

title: Rep. Tom Reed Says He Won't Run for Re-Election in 2022
summary: After allegations of inappropriate sexual conduct, the New York lawmaker said he wouldn't run for governor either. WASHINGTON-Rep. Tom Reed (R., N.Y.) said in a statement Sunday night he would not run for re-election or for governor in 2022, following allegations last week of inappropriate sexual conduct.

title: The Keys to Dealing With Chronic Uncertainty
summary: Planning and support can help us through the unpleasant surprises life keeps throwing at everyone a year into the pandemic. The first time I lost my child care this pandemic, I panicked. The second time, I cried. By the fourth time, I began half-jokingly polling my colleagues about which they thought might happen first: Would I write a story about women leaving the workforce, or would I have to leave myself? Every day started to feel like a coin toss. Heads, I can do my job...
